segments.text: Today is Sunday.
It is a beautiful morning, fall morning.
Roy, do you do you remember?
Who served in the bank here before Deadrich did?
Didn't Clapton Boss serve right after Deadrich?
Yeah.
Well, I know Deadrich.
Deadrich was the first man that I ever heard to bid in the bank.
Well, that's the only one I could.
They asked me the day before yesterday, and I said, Deadrich is the first man I can think of.
Now, if there was another one before then, I don't know it.
But I didn't know.
Well, now let me see.
Clapham Bar was, he was after debtors, I know because.
Yes, I know that.
I don't know who was before, now maybe, what about the Ropers?
Well, I just don't know.
I know that there was one of those that was connected with it at one time, but I don't remember.
They have this open over here at Marble Falls.
Yes.
The Roper House.
Yeah, the old Roper House.
That's right.
And I remember them because they named Roy Roper after me.
Yeah.
And he was my namesake.
I know that.
And that's a long time ago.
Yeah, that's been plenty years ago.
But I remembered, I knew that, too, that that was right.
They did.
And you know some one of the Browns.
Ed Brown.
Ed Brown.
That's who it was.
I couldn't think.
He lived here.
Old Man Shopper Brown lived down here.
He lived down here next to Earl Rickson.
I know all of that bunch down there.
And they...
And the Ulrichs, they just kept adding to their place.
Old man Ulrich, you know, he was an old miser.
Yes, he was.
He never spent a nickel for anything.
No, but he sure enough, he was getting the clapping bars, you know.
Oh, yes.
He married a clapping bar girl.
He married a clapping bar girl.
And so, you know, that all made a difference.
And I knew them from scratch.
And Helbert and all.
And Willie Gore never would have known, got out of the first root if it hadn't been for Helmuth Clappenbaugh.
Yeah.
That is, well, I have heard my daddy say that.
Oh, of course.
Everybody knew that.
But, you know, Willie would just tell stuff like, you know, he knew it all.
Nobody else knew anything.
And Clappenbaugh really passed him.
I know that.
That all worked out.
Yeah, Brown.
And Brown lived here and he had a grocery store here.
Old Man's Hopper.
They talked about Old Man Lawson called him, you know, from down the river.
Yes, down the river.
I rode old Spanish all the time, a little Spanish horse that I had.
Of course, he played out pretty quick.
And I got old Barney Gibbs then.
Old Man Al Grady used to ride all the time.
And they were my first two horses.
Then Dan Crowder gave me another horse called Billy Boy, a rolling horse.
I got up then to be about four or five years old and got to where I could ride.
Well, I think I was 10 years old when we, nine or 10, something like that, when we moved down to the place down on Miller Creek.
And Papa, Will Russell beat Papa for sheriff, you know, that year.
Yes.
He stayed on a couple of years, I think, and then quit.
But anyhow, they just had all that stuff going on.
You know, Uncle Buddy, Jay Chapman,
was Will Russell's clerk.
Or, you know, I said, today they call them deputies.
But he clerked what they called then clerk.
He kept the office and made out the tax reports and sheets and things and assessing work and all of that for the sheriff.
And believe it or not, 1901,
is when Russell built that house where Linden boyhood home.
And they, in place of getting the lumber from Fredericksburg, but on account of the sand being so heavy,
The horses and places along between, well, we always called it the old Schaefer Lane.
You couldn't hardly get through it.
It bogged down.
And that Blackland Field right below High Store.
And you just, the manuses and the...
Took all day to go to all of them?
Absolutely.
And you couldn't do it.
And they hauled that stuff out of here from New Brunsville.
My goodness.
Then cut through the pastures.
Yeah.
Oh, I know, gee whiz.
And I just, and knowing that, you know, when I tell them those things, they don't really believe it.
But I knew that Roy would remember about that as well as I did.
And do you know that old house that was just a two-room and a porch that Nat Stubbs did his law practice in, you know, down there?
Yeah, down here at this old house.
Yes, right down there, back of the old garage, right in there.
Well, you might say, well, he was...
In his backyard.
By the jail.
Yeah, back by the jail.
That's exactly right.
And there was an old hand-dug well back there.
And Vernon Crider's daddy, Rob Crider, bought that house and took it and built the house on the corner that leasemans live in today and stuccoed it.
That's the old Stubbs.
I didn't know that he bought it.
Yeah, he bought it.
Well, I didn't know whatever would come of it.
Yes, sir.
And you just took it away.
He bought it for $250 and took it up there in the original two rooms, just like it was.
He tore the porch off of it or set it up there in their stucco.
And that was the old Nat Stubbs office.
Well, I didn't know that.
That Rob Crider bought it.
Well, he did.
Rob Crider bought it.

that's one of the oldest houses is it now it's where uh right opposite the post office on the corner there oh and you know they've stuccoed it and built onto it but those two original rooms are still there oh meat market there yeah i knew all of that the harwood kids lived down there and all that say do you remember when mr when you lived up there on the river
across the river over at the place where old Manistrigler... Lickball.
Well, I was up one day, I was always trading with Mr. Johnson, you know.
Yeah.
He was just one of my best friends I ever had.
And so he took you and put you on the front and put Margaret in the middle and...
I bet it was Lennon.
Not Lennon.
James Ely?
James Ely put him behind.
And not a thing in the world on him.
He had a little old sorrow coat there, bald-faced coat.
And he walked up, kicked him in the end.
Yeah.
And he just wasn't running off.
His heart scared him.
And he went running his best right down through there.
And he just hollering and laughing as much as he could.
And we all fell off.
Man, the grass burrs all over everything.
And they just squalling and running every direction you ever saw.
And you remember that?
Oh, yes, I do.
And why he did that, I never could understand.
But he didn't care.
You know what he'd tell us?
He said, a good cowhand never squalled when it hit the ground.
And you know, he was trying to break us from crying.
But boy, those grass spurs would stick.
Oh, don't you know.
Oh, you bet.
Bull nettles.
And he'd always tell us that a good cowhand never squalled if he hit the dirt.
But I'll tell you.
I'll trade him old Arthur, an old horse I had.
Yes, I remember old Arthur.
Old Arthur swam that river and saved Tom Martin that time, don't you remember, my daddy?
He what?
Swam that Perknellis River in 1915 when he was high.
Oh, yeah, yeah.
That's right.
He took old Arthur.
Arthur would swim a river.
He would swim anything.
That's right.
I trained him down there in that creek.
Oh, oh.
Oh, down there at Harv Davis Place.
Yeah, that was the old lower...
Miller Creek.
Yeah, Miller Creek.
Yeah.
And do you know that Tom Martin was on a tree, willow tree, out, well, down below where the Texas White House is now.
And he, the river came down.
He started to cross in his buggy.
He'd been to Fredericksburg to see Olga Priest, whom he finally married.
And
He had washed his horse and buggy away, and he hung onto a tree.

And Papa came and got old Arthur, the one that Roy is talking about, and swam that river and put Tom on old Arthur, and he came out the river down below Grandpa Johnson's old place, which is a good mile from where he came in.
Now, I will tell you that, and the river was really high.
at that time.
But old Arthur knew about the rivers.
Yes, he did.
And I tell you what I did.
I traded him to him for two little old roan ponies, a year old and a two-year-old, and a brew horse that he got from old man Dederidge.
That's right.
Three.
He gave me the three for him.
You know the old... And then he got on him and he
The first time he got after a cab, he turned back so quick he fell off over his head.
Right, just kept riding.
That's right.
He would really turn.
You bet.
He was part perching, you know.
Oh, yeah.
And the first horse that I can remember that had a wavy mane.
You remember how wavy that mane?
Yeah, wavy mane and tail.
Mane and tail.
And the first one that I can ever remember having a wavy mane and tail.
That's the perching, you know.
Perching in them that showed up.
It sure did.
Of course, you know, that doesn't mean anything to the average horse.

boy or girl today but to me that was such a pretty thing to see that that wavy mane and papa kept it the four top trim just so oh and it was a pretty thing he was a good horse well he was a good looking horse you bet he's a good looking horse good looking horse and i tell you i like it i had well i had another one before no it was after i had author again and i got uh
Well, anyhow, Arnold Davis was working.
Arnold Hitzfeld was working for us down at this, oh, down where British dug for the gold, you know.
Yeah.
Well, he, anyhow, I was leading this horse for Arnold to ride.
As a mare, I believe.
Anyhow, he's riding up.
And he kept saying, give her slack, give her slack, give her slack.
And I kept giving more slack.
And so, you know, Arthur, he was used to whenever you stopped, he'd stop one.
You bet.
And if you run ahead of him, he'd just set back and stop.
Well, he just turned that horse, the Somerset, by a square back on him.

him, and it liked to kill him, he turned his back right under him, and if I hadn't had the help when I did, I guess it would have broke his back, but he fell sort of sideways, and he fell off in the thicket, and he sure let me hold that horse right after that, but he was a cow horse.
He sure was.
But I roped a cow on him one time, down at the

Phillips Ranch and he couldn't run fast enough on it just to barely catch a cow and I couldn't get enough slack to catch to take up the slack you know I couldn't yeah and so old Arthur was going just as hard as he could run and that cow was going right down into a canyon down into that blocker hauler canyon blocker canyon down where they used to round up cattle you know and put two
And I think, no, let me see.
I believe the Johnsons had that.
They had it.
Yes.
The blocker, huh?
They had that lease.
Yeah, I know they did.
So they, he was going just as hard as he could.
And I saw one of these, what you call these, Spanish oak.
Yeah.
Tickets down there.
to the left, to the right, I mean.
And so I just began to bear off as hard as I could.
That cow was going right down that canyon just with an old bell ringing and she was running and taking him as hard as she could and he couldn't run fast enough to cut her off.
And I was pulling as hard as I could and I saw that chick there and I went around on one side and she went on the other and I tell you, we met around there.
And Arthur,

She fell down, turned her feet square up, and Arthur fell square over, and his feet were up, and I went on around and circled around, holding the bridle rein as hard as I could, and like to kill me, you know, I was right on top of all those legs and things, and the fella come down, I believe it was Valdrick or somebody.
I imagine it was Val because he lived there.
Yeah, he lived on the place.
And so we finally got the thing settled up and she went on down and I didn't bother her either.
I never did look any more for her.
But he couldn't run fast enough to catch any, he could barely run fast enough to head a cow.
You know, B, people, you tell people today that these sage hills out here and all around here were not covered with Spanish oak back in the early days.
That's a come-late deal here.
No, we had very few.
When he said that Spanish oak thicket, let me tell you there were few and far between, and that was a landmark.
You'd say, well, I'll meet you at such and such place.
And the Spanish oak thicket down there on the other side of the gorge, you knew where it would be because there wasn't any Spanish oaks.
Very few in through here.
And another thing, the cedar, there wasn't any cedar.
No.
We didn't have cedar like we have now.
But what they did have was good cedar.
You bet.
It was virgin cedar.
It wasn't this come up and bush out.
It really was a different type.
This whole holding place down here on the river now where Dr. Burleson's old place, he has it all, everything, oh, it's old, old, old.
And...
The cedar is just as good today as it was the day it was cut.
It's all hard cedar.
That's right.
And you just think you're... Well, that old house that we tore down on the ranch down there was cypress lumber that was milled back in 18 and 58, and I'm taking the outside...
part of it and you can't cut it now you may think you can but uh those pieces that are short enough i'm going to use every one i'm on this porch and i'm going to burn in it when it was milled
And when it was borrowed, who put it up?
See, that old place that we have is a land grant place, and the deed to it is larger than a...
I mean, the land grant deed that was signed by Governor Davis of Texas is, well, I guess it's, I don't guess anything about it, but it's at least two feet long and two feet wide, square.
It looks like a big diploma of some description.

that I gave to Corky because naturally he'd be the one to get it but now that is something else and and to know that old old lumber is still going to be used oh it's good this is good it's still elastic just as good as it ever did and you know this that we had some ash
that were used for beams in that house.
My goodness, you can't cut it.
It's so solid and heavy as it can be.
How did they mill it then?
Well, when it's green, you can do it.
Oh, you can.
But after it seasons, it's just like rock.
Well, just a few people had a broad ax, you know, and they used it, you know, just like these size blades, you know.
I've got an old size blade out there, and I've got a cradle Grandfather Jackman used in cutting grain.
You know, he taught me how to stack hay, too.
Is that right?
He taught me.
They put me right on the stack with this.
Grandpa Chapman and he showed me just where to pull it and all that.
And we'd thrash and I'd stack.
And do you know, Bea, you have two different pitchforks.
One that you use to throw it on the wagon with and one you use to stack with.
That's right.
The handles are made different and the prongs are made different.
Right, Roy?
Three and four prongs.
That's right.
I didn't know that.
You bet that's right.
Mother asked me the other day.
She was out getting weeds out of my backyard and old dead grass.
And she said, have you got a pitchfork?
And I said, what in the hell use would I have for a pitchfork?
I haven't seen one since I was a kid.
I said, no, I got a shovel, but I sure as hell haven't got a pitchfork.
And I thought, well, Mother, you must be out of your mind.
Where would I get a pitchfork?
If I had one, I'd have it hanging in my house so nobody would steal it.
Well, when I told them that you had different styles for when I worked at the old Johnson settlement, do you know they looked at me
Like you're an idiot.
Like I was an idiot.
That's exactly right.
And they couldn't believe it.
Oh, that's right.
They had three and four prongs.
And you had to use one for one and one for the other.
And to stack it, it had a bowl.
I never will forget Mrs. Johnson.
We were across the river over there to Culberson Place, you know.
Yeah.
And the old house that lived over on the north side.
The north side of the, yeah.
And so this fellow Culberson, oh, I don't know whether he lived there then or not, but anyhow, he, Mr. Johnson was there, and they had the pens down there, too, up on the side of the hill.
And so, Mr., I don't know what, uh, uh,
James Eady was riding now, but some horse.
I'll bet he was riding.
It was a gentle horse, but anyhow, he says, hadn't even yet, James Eady, the slick rock crossing there, it's all slick.
It's bad.
You bet he sure was.
He went trotting off down that way and said, hurry up there, hurry up there.
Sitting up there like old Jim Chapman.
Make him run.
And James Ely never needed to get him into a run.
You know, he just lay him a trot.
And he's just like old Jim Chapman.
You know, Papa, my daddy would get after Ely more times than one because he wouldn't hustle.
But James Ely wasn't the fast-moving type.
He just never did get up in a hurry.
And Margaret and I were always just fast as lightning.
But James Ely was never quick, uh-uh, never in a hurry.
Well, I tell you that the old man Culberson, he lived there.
He says, Carl, don't let old Ray Ranger run away with you now.
And showing up.
Old Carl didn't care how you run.
He'd start home with him.
He'd start to running.
He'd just sit up there and whip him and let him go and run him just as hard as he could.
And he knew all was crazy about Bessie Scofield.
Oh, yeah.
He sure was.
You know...
You look back and think about these things in your early childhood.
Do you know it wasn't anything, or it didn't excite us, Margaret and I, one bit, if our daddy put us on a horse.
If he put us on there, he expected us to ride.
And he didn't expect us.
He would tell us that a horn of a saddle wasn't used to hold you.
It was used to wrap the rope around you.
I can remember that just as well if it is yesterday.
He said, if you want to stay on, you ride with your knees.
And I'll never forget that, you know, in riding.
Well, you do.
You clamp, and you hold tight, and your spurs will balance.
But you balance yourself with your reins, bridle reins, and it's not one person out of a hundred will do it.
That's right.
You're right.
If you're a good rider, you balance your...
He's gonna do that, too.
Oh, listen, Mr. Johnson was a good one, I tell you.
He was a real man.
He...
It tickles me.
I told Corky about that the other day.
I said, I don't know how old I was, but I was just a kid.
Just a little one.
Oh, I guess maybe I could have been 10, 11 years old, but not much more.
They was having races down here at Cypress Mills.
And Roy was looking for somebody to ride his horse.
He wanted to sell it for Polo Horse.
That's when all this bunch of Atlanta old
Yeah, those Hardin boys, they were good.
Yes, they were.
Margaret Burleson and I were there, and they mounted us on horses, and we rode in races at Cypress Mill just like veterans.
We mounted at the Kirkendall Ranch, too.
Yeah, down at the Kirkendall Ranch.
We went down there, and we went down and helped put on a show down there.
That's right.
We had races, you know, for the, and this, oh, yeah, I got one horse from, uh, Bernison.
Yeah?
That he was a racehorse.
If you'd whip him, he'd outrun any horse that they ever run him against.
And if you didn't whip him, he'd stop right in the middle of the track.
Absolutely.
You remember my daddy's hollering?
Daddy had the shrewdest voice.
Shrill, I mean.
And he'd say, put the bud to her, sister.
Put the bud to him.
And I'd just bring that old whip back just like that.
I can remember that just as well as it is yesterday.
But to think about...
Those things what you and then you see the youth of today.
They couldn't ride a stick horse around the block without falling down.
That's true.
But I guess I couldn't do a lot of it.
I'll tell you, you couldn't.
I couldn't ride a skateboard, and they can do that, so I guess it evens up.
I'd probably break my neck on a skateboard.
Nobody rides except barrel races and roping and things like that.
You couldn't pin a milk cow on a horse.
No, they couldn't do it to save their soul.
My daddy used to say, if you can't get on a horse and follow a cow, bring it in.
you'll just never amount to a hell of beans.
Well, we had to work.
We had to work hard.
We had to work day in and day out.
I was thinking about these whole steers, Tom Stribble, and we had to deliver them around the mountain.
And we
Well, we cut through the pasture.
Went through the hide pocket and then right straight on through.
You know what we had, though, when we got to Armand Ware's?
That's a horse of another color.
We had the detour there.
But anyway, we finally came out to old Salter Springs.
Mm-hmm.
And then brought them up the river, I mean up the lane there.
And got over to Ms. Stribling's, the old Stribling Ranch, and pinned them.
We would take them over to Marble Falls.
We had to help Tom drive those things into Marble Falls.
We spent the night there.
And I, Miss, Grandma Striblin had come in from the Zeke tank fishing, and she had a turtle, and she cooked that turtle, and she said to Margaret and I, said, well, you want something to eat supper?
And Margaret said, I'm awful hungry.
Tom said, well, Ma, give these kids something to eat.
They're hungry.
They've worked.
And so she gave us a bowl of turtle soup.
And Margaret looked at it, and she smelled it, and she said, what kind of soup is this?
She says, Tuttle soup.
Margaret pushed it back, and she asked me, said, aren't you going to eat that?
I said, no, ma'am.
I don't believe I'm hungry.
And she said, oh, you're too high-toned to eat turtle, I guess.
And Margaret said, I don't know whether I'm too high-toned, but I don't want turtle soup.
And then we walked out on the porch.
And Tom gave each one of us 20 cents.
And we went over to Blastie's store, and we brought a nickel box of crackers and a nickel box of sardines.
Can you beat that?
Yeah.
And then we got the rest of it in stick candy.
Oh, my gosh.
That's the way they did it.
I know that things like that happen.
You know it, and to think about it today is just unreal.
Yeah.
Sardines, 89 cents a can.
Yes.
Cheapest sardines.
Cheapest ones you can get.
Well, I tell you that Mr. Johnson, he was a good friend of mine.
Really a good friend of mine.
He worked us, I guarantee you.
But, you know, in reality, it didn't hurt you.
No.
You know, I rode old Carrie.
Old Carrie Nation?
He'd go to roping, loan me a horse, and take my horse, and ride my horse.
And I could rope a goat.
I could do that.
And I... Oh, no, I don't have anything for that.
Oh, no, unless you...
Another thing that was quite amusing was Sid Hyde.
You know, he's the best roper that you ever saw in the pasture.
He never caught one in the...
In an arena in his life.
You couldn't get him...
He couldn't catch one in the arena with a 100-foot...
rope or anything.
No, sir.
He just couldn't.
You put him in the brush, he'd just take and throw.
He'd just catch one any way you wanted him.
But he couldn't do it in front of people or in an arena to show off.
Well, Harry could do it.
Yeah, Harry could.
He could just run in.
And I let him have a horse one time.
I let Harry, not Harry, but Ed have a horse, a Dunn horse I called Butter.

brought him out at uh above Kerrville there and uh I don't remember where the shoemaker the fella had his horse and I paid a hundred and fifty dollars hundred dollars for him and I don't know I think I paid a good big price for it at that time but anyhow that horse was a racehorse he was Davis had the
Othello Davis had the sire on him.
And he, Rattler Cole, he was by Rattler, that's what it was.
And so he took pistol load and I was riding him when Dick was, I brought those horses down from Rock Springs and I came through Blanco's and missed having to go through, you know, quarantine.
Yeah.
And I got over there and then Dick was riding a little old Spanish mare.
